title: The Crucifixion of Christ
shortSummary: Luke 23 details the trial, suffering, crucifixion, death, and burial of Jesus Christ. This chapter reveals the fulfillment of prophecy, the innocence of Jesus despite false accusations, and His sacrificial death for the redemption of mankind. It highlights the responses of various individuals to Jesus’ passion and underscores the profound theological significance of His atoning work.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - The Passion Week, culminating in the crucifixion of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and Messiah, unjustly tried, crucified, and who willingly gave His life for the salvation of sinners.

keyCharacters.name: Pontius Pilate
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who, despite finding no fault in Jesus, capitulated to the crowd’s demand to crucify Him.

keyCharacters.name: Herod Antipas
keyCharacters.description: Tetrarch of Galilee who mocked Jesus but found no guilt in Him and sent Him back to Pilate.

keyCharacters.name: Simon of Cyrene
keyCharacters.description: A passerby compelled to carry Jesus’ cross on the way to Calvary.

keyCharacters.name: The Penitent Thief
keyCharacters.description: One of the two criminals crucified with Jesus who acknowledged Jesus’ innocence and asked to be remembered in His kingdom.

definitions.definition: A tax or payment made to a ruling authority, in this context the Roman Caesar.
A person who has committed a crime or offense; here referring to the criminals crucified alongside Jesus.
The day before the Sabbath when Jews prepared for the Sabbath rest; here it refers to the day before the Passover Sabbath.
The thick curtain separating the Holy of Holies from the rest of the temple, symbolizing the barrier between God and man.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Trial Before Pilate and Herod
outline.description: Jesus is accused by the chief priests and brought before Pilate, who finds no fault in Him. Pilate sends Jesus to Herod, who also finds no guilt but mocks Him before returning Him to Pilate. This section highlights Jesus’ innocence and the fulfillment of God’s sovereign plan despite human opposition.

outline.heading: Pilate’s Attempt to Release Jesus and the Crowd’s Demand
outline.description: Pilate offers to release Jesus, but the crowd demands Barabbas’ release and calls for Jesus’ crucifixion. Pilate ultimately yields to their demands, illustrating the injustice Jesus endured and the rejection of the Messiah by the people.

outline.heading: The Way to Calvary and Jesus’ Words to the Women
outline.description: Simon of Cyrene is compelled to carry Jesus’ cross. Jesus addresses the mourning women, warning them of coming judgment. This section reveals Jesus’ compassion and prophetic insight even in suffering.

outline.heading: The Crucifixion and Jesus’ Forgiveness
outline.description: Jesus is crucified between two criminals. He prays for forgiveness for His persecutors and promises paradise to the repentant thief, demonstrating His mercy and the offer of salvation even at the point of death.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Death and Burial
outline.description: Darkness covers the land, the temple veil is torn, and Jesus dies, commending His spirit to the Father. Joseph of Arimathaea requests Jesus’ body and lays Him in a new tomb. This section emphasizes the significance of Jesus’ death and the fulfillment of Scripture.

application: Trust in Jesus’ innocence and righteousness even when falsely accused or misunderstood, knowing He bore our sins on the cross.
Follow Jesus’ example of forgiveness by praying for those who wrong or persecute you.
Recognize the importance of repentance and faith, as shown by the penitent thief’s salvation at the last moment.
Honor the Sabbath and God’s commandments, as demonstrated by the women who prepared spices and rested according to the law.

keyVerses.text: Then said Jesus, Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do. And they parted his raiment, and cast lots.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ heart of forgiveness even toward His executioners, exemplifying divine mercy.

keyVerses.text: And Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, To day shalt thou be with me in paradise.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers of the promise of salvation and eternal life through faith in Christ.

keyVerses.text: And when Jesus had cried with a loud voice, he said, Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit: and having said thus, he gave up the ghost.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the voluntary and triumphant surrender of Jesus’ life into the Father’s hands, fulfilling His redemptive mission.

keyVerses.text: And a superscription also was written over him in letters of Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew, THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
keyVerses.significance: This inscription declares Jesus’ kingship, ironically placed by His enemies but truthfully affirming His identity as the Messiah.
